required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on October 07, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mental Health Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic Among Migrants in Chile
clinical_study.official_title: Mental Health Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic Among Immigrants in Santiago, Chile (STRING-COVID)

collaborator.agency: Fondo Nacional de Desarrollo Científico y Tecnológico, Chile

brief_summary.textblock:
Evidence suggests that social isolation affects mental health by increasing symptoms of anxiety and depression. One of the main components of the current COVID-19 pandemic is the social isolation imposed on the population. This study seeks to assess the impact of the physical and social living conditions of the pandemic in a cohort of urban immigrants in Chile (i.e. STRING) evaluated six months prior to the pandemic.
Specific aims are to
1. Describe the variations in the levels of mental health of immigrants during and after the pandemic,
2. Calculate the effect of social isolation on the levels of mental health of the immigrant population, and
3. Identify risk / protective factors associated with increased mental health problems
An online survey will be applied to the STRING cohort at two moments of the pandemic (i.e. during quarantines and after six months).

primary_outcome.description: The Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9; Kroenke, Spitzer & Williams, 2001) is used to measure symptoms of depression in accordance with the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder. The questionnaire consists of nine items scored on a four-point Likert scale (0-3), with the range of scores from 0 to 27. Higher scores indicate greater depression severity, and scores above 10 are considered as the cut-off that indicating that the patient is within the depressive area. Specific cut-off for primary care samples in Chile have been found yielding a cut-off of 7 and above for high sensitivity and specificity (Saldivia, Aslan, Cova, Vicente, Inostroza & Rincón, 2019)

The Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 (GAD-7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams & Löwe, 2006) is used to measure symptoms of anxiety and worry. The questionnaire consists of seven items scored on a four-point Likert scale (0-3), with the scores ranging from 0 to 21. Specific cut-off for primary care samples in Spain have been found yielding a cut-off of 10 and above for high sensitivity and specificity (García-Campayo et al, 2010).

The Impact of Events Scale (IES-R; Weiss & Marmar, 1997) is used to measure symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). There scale consists of 22 questions which are scored on a five-point Likert scale (0=not at all, 1=a little bit, 2=moderately, 3=quite a bit, 4=extremely). There are three subscales (i.e., avoidance, intrusion, hyperarousal) and the sum of the three subscales scores comprise the total score. A total score ≥33 indicates the likely presence of PTSD using criteria from the Diagnostic Symptom Manual (DSM-IV).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in mental health symptoms, well-being from last 2 weeks before the pandemic to last 2 weeks during COVID-19 pandemic
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from last 2 weeks before pandemic to month 1 (first follow-up)
primary_outcome.description: Change in visual analogue scale-assessed transdiagnostic measures across all psychiatric symptoms, and World Health Organization (WHO)-5 well-being in the last 2 weeks compared to the last 2 weeks of "regular life" before the COVID-19 outbreak.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from last 2 weeks before pandemic to month 1 (first follow-up)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in general physical health, self-rated, on a VAS scale from 0 to 100

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from last 2 weeks before pandemic to month 1 (first follow-up)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in general mental, self-rated, on a VAS scale from 0 to 100

study_pop.textblock: The STRING cohort is comonsed of 1,092 adults residing in private households in the Metropolitan Region of Santiago, Chile who were born outside of Chile and had lived in the country for at least 3 months in the first wave.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Country of birth other than Chile
- Time since arrival to Chile: 3 months (at baseline)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to understand Spanish
